body: Suggestion is to make WriteResultHandler and the interface as unstable as we may change it down the road.
done

The code is modified to address a RM issue by adding MultipleRMUrlProvider. This also removed the dependency on the named parameter for the  yarn web address keys. 
I changed some of the names, e.g. SubmitAndGetDriverUrl to SubmitAndGetJobStatus. 
For IDriverHttpEndpoint, as it represents something returned from submit, so I named it as IJobSubmissionResult. 
For the code inside JobSubmissionResultImpl, originally named HttpEndPoitHelper, it needs some clean up. I am not sure if we should do it in a separate Jira or wait until rest API is done. 
The change so far has pushed in.

A  slightly more robust way of handling the case when the tcpPortProvider returns no free port might be this:
1) Instantiate the second tcpPortProvider and try to find a free port with it. This provider should try all ports form the widest possible range, e.g. all ports that are not well-known.
2) Fail only if the second provider returns nothing.

The rationale behind this approach  is that there might be something wrong with the first tcpPortProvider - such as too narrow port range - or  there might exist some temporary weird contention in the underlying OS.

However, I don't know how to correctly create the second provider within a Tang-injectable constructor. This looks like a dependency and probably also should be injected via Tang.
I added more documentations for `TODO: Document.` cases.

I don't think the more robust way is in fact more robust. The reason we needed the port provider in the first place are clusters on which only a very narrow range of ports is allowed by the infrastructure. Trying a much wider range would just lead to timeouts on those.
I will review/test and merge.

One more broad level comment: Maybe we could split this PR into two:
1. Convert the current code from using command line parameters to the new Avro-serialized object.
2. Add the code that moves the Java configuration to the Driver side.

That way, we can unify the two code paths and also move from working to working.

I'm +0 on merging this.

My remaining concerns are philosophical, not related to the code: This PR adds Avro schemas that almost, but not fully, duplicate the protobuf messages used between Driver and Evaluators. They also almost, but not completely, duplicate the messages exchanged between C# and Java in the C# Driver.
I'm concerned about the long-term maintainability of this.

We should have a discussion about evolving these three copies of essentially the same schemas into one coherent set, maybe a new subproject `reef-schemas` or such.
@markusweimer Thanks for the input. May I ask you a concrete suggestion to fix this PR to make your vote +1?
@afchung I've done a pass.

There is none. Go ahead and merge this, as it is a net improvement on REEF. My concerns need to be addressed more longer term, if at all.

If you want to do one thing, mark all of the new public types in here as `@Unstable`. That way, we are not beholden to them if and when we get around to unifying the schemas.
All these files will need Apache license headers. If they can't be licensed that way, we should add their heritage to the `NOTICES` file.

But, if you want, there is no problem to do that.
We should have the license headers OR add them to the `NOTICES` file. What's the heritage of these files? Did you write them all?

Change pushed in. 
@markusweimer can you review/merge it?

When you schedule a container onto a cluster, that container might really just be a process on a box. Which means that it shares the network connection with all other processes (containers) on that same box. If you now configure ports statically and two of your containers end up on the same host, only the first will be able to bind to that port. The second container will fail, as the port is already taken.

The common way around this is to use `0` as the port number. That signals to the OS to pick any of the available ports.

However, we ran into issues with that approach on clusters with two levels of firewalls: The one of the OS, but also an outer one (e.g. on the host if the OS is virtualized). In that case, the OS has no idea of the external firewall configuration and will happily open a port that will be blocked by the outer firewall. In order to overcome this, we've added the `TcpPortProvider` mechanism: It returns available ports to whomever needs them and can be configured by the user for the cluster at hand.
